data.text:
In the late 1960s, the “New Hollywood” era approached a new style of filming geared towards different generations of people. Leading up to new Hollywood, the 1960s brought devastation to the film industry. With the massive production of televisions along with the migration of millions to suburbs away from the cities, movie theaters lost their popularity very quickly. Fewer films were being made, thus hurting Hollywood in every way possible. However, as the late 1960s approached, the new Hollywood era arose with new ways to attract movie-goers once more. Although, the movies released started to attract younger generations, so the industry capitalized on this trend by releasing cheaper movies, of which some became critically acclaimed. In doing so, the industry was able to make similar, cheap movies that attracted more and more teenagers. Movies like monster movies and outlaw movies made the most money which helped Hollywood get back on their feet. Outlaw movies like Bonnie and Clyde and Easy Rider became popular because they both have similar plot lines that are based on going against the system and “fighting the man”. We can see a similarity with these two movies as they both break the law and run away to become free. For example, Clyde gets Bonnie and others hooked on robbing banks to fight the Great Depression they are currently in. They break the law, fall in love, have gun battles with the cops, and generally have a fun time with it. Teenagers are always interested in this type of action and getting back at the system. In Easy Rider, Captain America and Billy make a huge drug deal and run off with their money, smoke marijuana all day long, have sex, and do other substances along their journey. This outlaw-ish behavior was what teenagers and young adults were doing at this time. In the late 1960s, marijuana and other substances became largely popular, rock and roll was popular, all of the things Captain America and Billy do could be very similar to what was actually going on in America at the time; therefore the audience can relate to the characters.
